READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 398, 740, 413]]<|/det|> Write your centre number, candidate number and name in the spaces at the top of the page. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 413, 300, 427]]<|/det|> Write in dark blue or black pen. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 427, 479, 441]]<|/det|> You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 440, 479, 454]]<|/det|> Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 453, 359, 467]]<|/det|> DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 478, 243, 492]]<|/det|> Answer all questions. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 492, 818, 507]]<|/det|> You are advised to spend about 20 minutes on each of questions 1 to 3, and 15 minutes on question 4. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 507, 339, 520]]<|/det|> Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 520, 730, 535]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 545, 576, 559]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 559, 722, 574]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[675, 616, 861, 802]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[74, 68, 92, 85]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 67, 821, 85]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will determine the weight of a metre rule using a balancing method. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 98, 549, 115]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[87, 140, 855, 273]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 289, 507, 307]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 319, 141, 337]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[181, 319, 876, 367]]<|/det|> Place the metre rule on the pivot. Place the load \(\mathbf{P}\), labelled \(1.5\mathbf{N}\), on the metre rule at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark. Keep \(\mathbf{P}\) at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark and adjust the position of the metre rule on the pivot so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 378, 175, 396]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 378, 728, 396]]<|/det|> In Table 1.1, record the distance \(a\) from the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark to the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 408, 175, 426]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 408, 728, 426]]<|/det|> In Table 1.1, record the distance \(b\) from the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark to the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 435, 175, 454]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 435, 517, 454]]<|/det|> Calculate \(\frac{a}{b}\). Record its value in Table 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 465, 175, 484]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 465, 774, 484]]<|/det|> Repeat the procedure using the loads labelled \(1.2\mathbf{N},\) \(1.0\mathbf{N},\) \(0.8\mathbf{N}\) and \(0.5\mathbf{N}.\) <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[435, 495, 514, 513]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[242, 521, 707, 683]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[72, 69, 89, 85]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[109, 69, 875, 115]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the time taken for metal balls to stop moving after being released on a curved track. Fig. 4.1 shows the shape of the track. The track is flexible, so the shape of the curve can be changed.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 168, 751, 292]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[442, 332, 507, 349]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 4.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 362, 400, 378]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 392, 462, 407]]<|/det|>
a selection of metal balls of different masses

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 406, 250, 420]]<|/det|>
the flexible track

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 420, 303, 436]]<|/det|>
clamps to hold the track

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 435, 215, 450]]<|/det|>
a stopwatch

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 450, 240, 465]]<|/det|>
a tape measure

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 465, 215, 480]]<|/det|>
a metre rule

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 494, 875, 526]]<|/det|>
The student can also use other apparatus and materials that are usually available in a school laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 540, 875, 571]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate a factor that affects the time taken for metal balls to stop moving after being released on a curved track. You are **not** required to carry out this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 584, 309, 600]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 613, 536, 628]]<|/det|>
· describe how you would expect the balls to move

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 642, 536, 658]]<|/det|>
· explain how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 672, 813, 687]]<|/det|>
· state which variables you would keep constant and which variable you would change

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 701, 875, 732]]<|/det|>
· draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 745, 650, 761]]<|/det|>
· explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 774, 631, 790]]<|/det|>
You may add to the diagram in Fig. 4.1 if it helps your explanation.
